title: Jim Calder (rugby union)
text:
James Hamilton Calder (born 20 August 1957) is a former <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland</a> international <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player.
Rugby Union career.
Amateur career.
He played club rugby for <a href="Stewart%27s%20Melville%20RFC">Stewart's Melville</a>.
Provincial career.
He played for <a href="Edinburgh%20District%20%28rugby%20union%29">Edinburgh District</a>. He was part of the side that won the <a href="1986%E2%80%9387%20Scottish%20Inter-District%20Championship">1986–87 Scottish Inter-District Championship</a>.
He played for the <a href="Reds%20Trial">Reds Trial</a> side in their match against <a href="Blues%20Trial">Blues Trial</a> on <a href="1986%E2%80%9387%20Scottish%20Inter-District%20Championship">3 January 1987</a>.
International career.
He received 2 caps for <a href="Scotland%20B%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland 'B'</a> in 1980.
His full international debut came in 1981 aged 21 against France. Scotland were on the receiving end of a 16–9 loss. He scored the winning try in Scotland's 21–12 victory over France at Murrayfield in 1984 which gave Scotland its first Grand Slam since 1925.
In 1983 he toured New Zealand with the <a href="British%20%26amp%3B%20Irish%20Lions">British & Irish Lions</a>.
Family.
His twin brother, <a href="Finlay%20Calder">Finlay Calder</a>, also played for Scotland and captained the <a href="1989%20British%20Lions%20tour%20to%20Australia">1989 British Lions tour to Australia</a>. The brothers never played in the same Scotland side; Jim Calder won the last of his caps against in March 1985 and Finlay made his debut against in January 1986. Jim won a total of 27 caps, with his career record ending as: Won 12, Lost 13, Drew 2.
His two sons, Duncan and <a href="Lewis%20Calder">Lewis</a>, have also represented Scotland at U21 level. Duncan, his elder son, retired from the game due to knee problems.
He also has a daughter called Hannah.
